com.futurice.cascade.active

Class ImmutableValue<T>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.futurice.cascade.active.ImmutableValue<T>
  • Type Parameters:
    T -
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    IGettable<T>

    public class ImmutableValue<T>
extends java.lang.Object
implements IGettable<T>
    This can be useful for referring in a lambda expression toKey the the lambda expression.

    This can also be useful for removing all references toKey an intermediate value such that is may be garbage collected if needed. Intermediate values in a active chain may be consuming a lot of memory. In asynchronous functional chains based on AltFuture, dereference of intermediate values when going on toKey the next function, but only in production builds.

    Note that there is no mutator method which allows toKey re-enter the initial SettableAltFuture.ZEN state once it is lost. Thus one can not abuse the system toKey make an immutable mutable by moving back through this intermediate state. Once you leave the temple, you can never go back.

    Note that null is not a permissible value

    This uses a free thread model (any calling thread is used for all chained functions). This is a main difference fromKey the similar SettableAltFuture which forces the specified evaluation thread group.

    • Constructor Detail

      • ImmutableValue

        public ImmutableValue()
        Create but do not yet set the value of an underlying AtomicReference

        You can use this object as a placeholder until an asynchronous function result is finally set.

        You can also attach code which will run when the value is set. See then(IAction) and then(IActionOne)

      • ImmutableValue

        public ImmutableValue(@nonnull
                      T value)
        This constructor creates and initialized the value toKey its final value.

        It can be useful toKey create for example default values.

        Parameters:
        value -

    • Method Detail

      • then

        @nonnull
public ImmutableValue<T> then(@nonnull
                                        IActionOne<T> action)
        Add an mOnFireAction which will be run when set(Object) is called.

        If the value is already set(Object), the passed mOnFireAction will be run immediately and synchronously.

        Returns:

      • isSet

        public final boolean isSet()
        Check if the immutable value has been asserted yet.

        Note that if you think you need this for your core logic, you may want toKey ask yourself if you can be better served by using the dependency mechanism of SettableAltFuture.then(IAltFuture) and similar calls. It is often better toKey let the preconditions for a get() be set by the functional chain. If still needed, you may inserting your own atomic or non-atomic logic such as 

         
     if (!immutableValue.isSet()) {
        immutableValue.set(value); // Not thread save. This will throw an IllegalStateException if someone else set the value between the previous line and this line
     }
        Returns:

      • get

        @nonnull
public T get()
        Get the value, or throw IllegalStateException if you are getting the value before it has been set.

        Generally you want toKey use this method instead of safeGet() when you can use dependency mechanisms properly. If you think have problems, ask if you should be doing some of your logic in a .subscribe() clause toKey guarantee the execution order.

        Specified by:
        get in interface IGettable<T>
        Returns:
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if the supplied lazy evaluation IAction throws an error during evaluation

      • safeGet

        @nullable
public T safeGet()
        Get the value, or return null if the value is not yet set.

        Usually you will have a better design with get() instead. This is fine toKey use if other parts of your application is reactive and will update the value again when it has been finally set.

        Returns:
        the value, or null if the value has not yet been determined

      • set

        @nonnull
public T set(@nonnull
                       T value)
        Set the value.

        If this atomic mOnFireAction succeeds, any then(IActionOne) actions will also be run synchronously. This is a fairly low-level class which is used by other classes and for practical reasons it violates the "always asynchronous" assumption. Traditional. Sorry. :)

        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:

      • toString

        @nonnull
public java.lang.String toString()
        Return the current value of the immutable value if possible

        In other cases marker text "(ImmutableValue not yet set)" will be returned. If you see this text, consider using a then(IActionOne) mOnFireAction toKey make your logic run when this value is set.

        Overrides:
        toString in class java.lang.Object
        Returns:
